Fragment: What Diapasons more in Tarquins [Lord] name Then in a Subiects?
More in the sound, then to become the name Of a poore Maide or waiting Gentlewoman?
my title beares no breadth,
Sick at heart.
I long, long and am sicke With ardence,
my hot appetite's afire, Till my swolne feruor be deliuered Of that great Title Queene,
my heart's all royal, Not to be circumscribed in servill bounds,
my prowd heart cannot brooke it [obeysance].
Oh had God made me man, I would haue mounted Aboue the base tribunals of the earth, Vp to the clowdes, for pompeous soueraintie,
Mount heauen and see if Tullia [woman] lag behinde,
There is no earth in me, I am all fire, Were Tarquin [man] so, then should we both aspire.
though my body taste of dulnesse,
My soule is wingde: loe I soare as high as thine, But note what flags our wings!
And but by Seruius [the king's] fall we cannot climbe,
The balme that must annoynt vs is his [the king's] blood.
Lets laue our browes then in that crimson flood,
in my swathed Infancye,
They all imbrace my faction,
heart pure, as vnblemisht Innocence.
Heeres modell, yea, and matter [succession] too to breed Strange meditations in the prouident braines Of our graue Fathers:
some strange proiect liues This day in Cradle thats but newly borne.
heeres a giddie world, it Reeles, it hath got the staggers,
the common-wealth is sicke of an ague, of which nothing can cure her but some violent and suddaine affrightment.
and [the queen] longes to be brought to bed of a Kingdome,
a generall concourse of wise-men, tw'as neuer seene since the first Chaos.

[the state] which my sword must pierce, To purge th'infected blood:
bred by the pride Of these infested blouds,
embrace his faction,
Words worth an Empire.
Strumpet, no childe of mine.
Dotard, and not my father.
our awe is builded Vpon this royall base, and slaughtered body Of a dead King;

my birth was seruitud
this new breath of reigne is large and free,
Welcome my second life of Soueraintie.
should my Lucrece [daughter], Be of this pride, thefe handes should sacrifice Her blood vnto the Gods that dwell belowe,
The abortiue brat should not out liue my spleene,
Teare off the crowne, that yet empales the Temples Of our vsurping Father
And in the face of his [father's] yet bleeding woundes, Lets vs receiue our honours.
The same breath Giues our state life, that was the Vsurpers death.
Heere then by heauens hand we inuest our selues:
Great Tarquins [king] life is in our hearts desirde.
Shall with our dreadles hands, our hearts commaund,
Our selues are vassailes to the Roman state.
In whose submission our young glorie growes To his ripe height:
strengthen with your loues our Infant raigne.
whilst Iustice keepes thy Sword & thou thy Throane.

with his base confederates strewe the streets, That in disgrace, of his vsurped pride,

Those Giants that wagde war against the Gods, For which ore-whelmed Mountaines hurld by Ioue, To scatter them, and giue timelesse Graues, Was not more cruell then this butcherie.
did not this shee parracide add to her fathers wounds:

the fruite of pride is yet but greene, Not mellow, though it grows apace, it comes not To his ful height:
Pride when thy fruite is ripe must rot and fall.
His soaring high make vs to flag our winges, And fly close by the earth,
his golden feathers, Are of such Vastnes that they spread like sailes, And so become vs that we haue not ayre,
[the air] to raise our plumes, to taste the pleasures of our owne Elements.
We are one harte, our thoughts & our desires are sutable.

He has vsurpt a stranger garbe of humour,
can his eies forbeare, In this strange state to shed a passionate teare,

giuen vp the Court And weand himselfe from the kings consistory In which his sweet harmonious tongue grew harsh, […] now hee's all musicall.

thy passionate eyes lament with mine,
